title: Information flows, attention, bridges
segmentation: Alright, so I'm glad I work at socialflow.
It's a New York based startup.
We do a lot of let me just move this back down.
We do a lot of social data analysis and build a variety of tools for publishers.
So today I'm going to take a quite like a different spin on the story.
I'm going to go through a bunch of examples of data that is really valuable and it's really exciting.
I think, for the industry, for journalists from news organizations, so we all know there's a ton of data out there.
Proliferation of social media means anyone can post anything at any moment, and attention has become the bottleneck, right?
It used to be publishing.
It is now attention, and we cannot require or.
We cannot demand attention from our audience at specific times, right?
We have to understand them.
We have to understand their behavior, what they tend to post, what they tend to reshare.
Yes, this is from Flickr, that ancient ancient old site.
So so yes, so we have to understand how how our audience manage is their intention in order to understand how information flows, right?
And by understanding these informations flows, we can we can start to get a sense for what works with our audiences, what information, what pieces of data manages to propagate, what does less.
Is all because because the like within these social networks that people are the ones passing the data right?
They are re sharing their reposting.
So if we want if we want data to pass forward we have to look at these info.
Nation flows and how they manage their attention.
Now many of you would be amazed or horrified that there are 46,000 people who follow both the economists and Justin Bieber.
Now, who are these people?
I have absolutely no clue, but just that single little fact tells us something.
Some nugget about an audience about our audience.
If we were the economists, we might, and we were seeking to sort of engage more of our audience.
We might actually take a look at that snippet of data and and start sort of.
Trying to understand.
OK, so who are these 46,000 people?
What else do they what?
Who else do they follow?
And maybe we can sort of target?
More of our more of our articles to actually to their interests.
One of the things we do are sort of these.
These word Maps that look at topics that people in audiences are discussing.
So the one to the right.
The right is a snapshot of an hours worth of data from Twitter from the audience of Fox News, right?
It's very very clear, and this is not this is these are people who follow Fox News on Twitter, right?
This is not searching for a hashtag or this is like the whole data set.
So it's very clear from a portion of the graph that sort of the domain of Fox News is also very much aligns with the interests of their audience in comparison Al Jazeera's audience.
This again a section of the graph, but I'll just.

There's a large section of Aljazeera's audience that like constantly discuss is Middle East topics Tahrir Square Jan 25 now that so again by looking at the topics that our audiences are discussing in real time, we have the ability to know what we're covering and if there is something else we should be covering and we can get this data in real time with tools that are available.
Nowadays this is really interesting.
This is based on click data, so this is based on Bitly data for the top clicks generated by top articles that generated the most clicks for these different news media outlets.
So we see Aljazeera is pretty predictable, a lot of Middle East News video.
New York Times that day was running a big story on basketball and yell fraternity.

The Economist is the most unique of them all, so we're talking about a variety of world topics and yogurt and and Fox News is actually it's pretty amazing in staggering, but not not very surprising that the top words from articles that are posted by Fox News are crime Casey Anthony, murder kidnapper.
And transgender clownfish.
I recommend you all to go look at that article.
It's actually fascinating, no, but what this tells us actually is.
Also, it's another level of alignment, right between what the audience is actually clicking on, right?
This is the invisible stuff we don't see from Twitter.
This is the stuff that represents a lot of those.
A lot of those.
So like we call them passive, right?
The readers, but they're not that passive right there.
Actually, clicking on the stuff that we share on Twitter.
One interesting aspect of this data is if you look at so if you compare the for media outlets.
The Economist gets the most clicks per tweet with a link that shared, but we see we see this really interesting thing happened where Aljazeera?
Is actually Aljazeera is generating like a lot of retweets and has a really engaged audience on Twitter right?
Like people who are somewhat more advanced but they're not actually clicking as much on data.
So when we normalize by the size of the audience and we compare Fox News with Al Jazeera, we see that Fox is generating like a lot more clicks than Aljazeera.
And this begs the question like are we as a news organization?
Do you?
Do you want to maximize clicks?
'cause actually what Fox News is doing here is it's probably putting some really great titles, right?
Really great titles to the articles that are getting people to press that.
Press that button, press that link.
Whereas Aljazeera is possibly generating content that is interesting.
I mean people are still engaging with Aljazeera following Aljazeera.
But not clicking on that content?
So what does that mean for medial to create this audience that clicks an like generating traffic goes and looks at these ads on their website versus.
Aljazeera which is creating this audience that is much more engaged and much more participation participatory on Twitter but doesn't generate as much money in real time.
This is one study we published a few a couple of months ago by now, and it's the propagation of the tweet that sort of broke the news about Osama bin Laden.
So the big story after the White House announcement that Osama bin Laden was killed, was that.
Twitter broke the news, but nobody really knew what happened.
So we went back into the data and actually tried to figure out.
Trying to figure out who the first person was and what happened at that.
Critical time.
And what we saw was so from 9 about 9:00 PM PST, where the announcement that there was going to be a White House announcement came out.
There was a ton of rumors on Twitter, right?
Lots of people saying is that bin Laden?
Is it Gaddafi?
What could it be?
Why do they have to have an announcement on Sunday night?
Why couldn't they moved to Monday?
It has to be big, right?
And there was a single point in time, but you see around like right before 10, where bin Laden really took off.
So what?
Happened there, we tracked it down to the single tweet posted by Keith Urbane, who's Donald Rumsfeld's chief of staff and he wrote this.
So I'm told by a reputable person they've killed Osama bin Laden.

Hot damn, I'm sure he wishes that hot damn wasn't there, but this tweet within a minute was retweeted 80 times within 2 minutes 300 times, and really like propagated through the network in a way that would not have been predictable if you just looked at his profile 'cause he had like.
800 followers and and wasn't that like it wasn't an authority on Twitter.
Not someone you would recognize as an authority, yet he generated.
Like all this trust from from the network and you see Brian Stelter, New York Times Reporter who retweeted Keith Urban within minutes and just the whole network.
Was generated within minutes, right within 10 minutes.
Thousands of people were reposting the fact that Osama bin Laden was captured, right?
So So what does it mean now that?
Also, that news organizations and the White House can't break news anymore?
Because this, we see this happening more and more.
I.
An interesting aspect of the story that came out that week was the story about really virtual.

This Twitter account is this Pakistani geek who is actually he was posting from his home in a boat Abad and he was just like really complaining about the helicopters in the sound blasts and he was just trying to get some sleep.
But he did not realize at the time that he was effectively live tweeting the operation.
Right, and what happened when that when that was realized, he sort of he became this sort of Star Citizen.
Journalists with, you know, 10s of thousands of followers and all these media organizations coming to him to get get information from him.
But in effect, if you go back and look at how that bridge formed, it's really interesting because his network was extremely different from from sort of the Western network or twittersphere, right?
He was not connected at the time to anyone in.
Europe or or in the United States.

The way this bridge formed was actually a really curious Forbes Blogger who that night, after the announcement of the White House was was using Google Real Time Search to be like, hey, I wonder if I could find something and started looking up terms like Bomb Blast, helicopter and and I think Urdu translations of those terms in Pakistan.
And she found this guy who tweets in English and was right there and was talking about the blasts and all these lights.
And she wrote to him.
She was like, I think you just live, tweeted the the raid and he was like I guess so.
And the next day he was a superstar, right?
So it's interesting that we talk about networks and bridging in the form of like these networks that form.
But actually bridges can happen dynamically with someone who uses technology just really well or really in an innovative matter.
Are another form of bridging that I'm really fond of is a global voices and that's a community I've been part of for the last couple of years.

I cover the Hebrew blogosphere for global voices, and for those of you who don't know with global voices, it's a community of bloggers from all around the world who translate local news from their language.
From the local language into English.
And then it's translated into other prominent languages.
And this is exactly this solves the point of the core of what global voice is trying to do is amplify voices that would never.
Never be heard otherwise, so it's an it's an amazing community and it's really a great product to be part of.
The one thing that I would I would say is I'm not sure.
Like I would, I wonder how many bridges and how many like new community communities that actually brings the information to.

Because for me, yes, I feel like without global voices there is no way I would have been able to discuss these topics with people from Iran from Iraq, from Syria, Lebanon, and we cover events like the flotilla event together so it gets extremely tense when someone covers the Israeli side, which is me.
And then.

The other rest covered the the other side, but we saw that we work through it and we hash it out and we discussed but the end of the day, the audience that comes to the site are extremely sort of pro.
You would call them more pro Arab.
There are very few Israelis who actually come to global voices and read the news.
So I'll end with just a little need graph, which is.
It's a typical graph showing the sharing of a story from from the Middle East from Israel, Palestine.
You see the the Israeli contingent at the bottom highly clustered sort of sharing the one V1 Israeli view.
You see the Palestinian contingent at the top, which is?
I mean, it barely exists on Twitter.
This is based on Twitter and just a few a few tiny bridges in the middle.
People who follow and bridge the two opinions.
And I'd like us to think about this paradox, where like we're all in these social networks together.
We're all you know, one hop away one or two hops away from each other, but information rarely flows, right.
It's hard for like Israelis to actually follow or see the Palestinian side, and vice versa.
It just doesn't.
So I end with that.
